chapter.title: Parameter Estimation Techniques
chapter.para: this chapter needs to discuss how to estimate para with out calibration data and how to check your calibration parameters are within a reasonable range

listitem.para: parameter interaction - multiple parameters sets for same outcome/calibration
how to go about parameter estimation

section.title: introduction
section.para: what do we mean by a parameter, what are we considering as parameter estimation. Adjustable parameters? measured parameters, infered parameters. model inputs that are actually parameters (catchment area, slope, cross sections, land use). Many topographic parameters are dependent on map scale or the resolution of the underlining data or the algorithm used to sample the data.
most catchments do not have suitable data for a full calibration and validation but enough to inform the catchment response.

rarely do you have enough data, when you do, it becomes hard to reconcile all of the calibration outcomes. easy to calibrate to limited data (assumed perfect), hard to calibrate to multiple data points ().
trying to get the representative response of the catchment (or for various inputs, particularly when extrapolating as because there is always less data at the extreme end),

section.title: Parameter Estimation
section.para: approaches in estimation of parameters (for a range of calibration data)

section.title: Calibration Process
section.para: most calibration is done by hand or manual. automatic calibration apporaches rreplicate hand calculations.
measures of calibration success - potential biases, relationship to hydrograph characteristics (peak flow and levels, rate of rise, volumes)
how good is the calibration, how do you measure this and what is "good enough"
